The Zr-modified CeTiOx mixed oxide catalyst with good NH3-SCR activity and SO2 resistance was synthesized and reduced by H2. Performance test revealed that the obtained R-CZT-20/1 (Ce: Zr: Ti = 20: 1: 100) catalyst exhibited outstanding low-temperature activity after H2 reduction treatment, which achieved upon 98% NO conversion at 200–350 °C. Remarkably, it possessed excellent SO2 resistance as well as good reversibility, with the activity decreased from 100% to 96%. Meanwhile, R-CZT-20/1 possessed more surface acid sites and oxygen defects, which promoted the chemical adsorption and activation of NO and NH3 on the catalyst surface. XPS results confirmed that R-CZT-20/1 enriched Ce3+, accelerated the electron transfer between Ce3++ Ti4+ → Ce4++ Ti3+, and generated a large number of oxygen vacancies. Moreover, there is strong synergistic effect between Ce-Zr-Ti, which might be the reason for the excellent SO2 resistance. Among them, the presence of Zr facilitated the favorable process. In situ DRIFTS experiments indicated that the unreduced catalysts followed E-R and L-H mechanism at low and high temperatures, respectively, while R-CZT-20/1 obeyed only the L-H mechanism. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords NH3-SCR H2 reduction Zr-modified SO2 resistance Enriched Ce3+ 1 Introduction As the main pollutant in the air, nitrogen oxides (NOx) mainly come from stationary and mobile sources (such as coal-fired power plants, motor vehicle exhaust, etc.) [1,2]. With the deterioration of the environment, it is urgent to eliminate NOx pollution. Among various NOx control and reduction technologies, selective catalytic reduction of NOx by NH3 (NH3-SCR) is considered to be one of the most promising methods for removing NOx from stationary sources [3–5]. V2O5-WO3/TiO2 is widely used in commercial SCR catalysts due to its high activity and anti-SO2 poisoning. However, the catalyst can only operate at a high temperature of 300–400 °C with a narrow temperature window, which cannot eliminate NOx in the exhaust gas below 300 °C from glass furnaces, metal sintering furnaces and cement plants [6,7]. In addition, other disadvantages of these catalysts, such as poor thermal stability, biotoxicity of vanadium and high-temperature reaction resulting in large amounts of N2O, limit the application of vanadium-based DeNOx catalysts [8]. Thus, it is necessary to develop an environmentally friendly catalyst with excellent NH3-SCR activity at low temperature. In recent years, a lot of research has been done on low temperature SCR catalysts, including transition and rare earth metal oxides catalysts, such as Mn-based: Mn-Ti [9–12], Mn-Ce [13,14], Mn-Sm [15–17]; Ce-based: Ce-Sn [18,19], Ce-Zr [20,21], Ce-Ti [22,23] catalysts. Among them, Ce-Ti catalyst has attracted widespread attention on account of their good oxygen storage capacity (OSC) and rich Ce4+ ↔ Ce3+ redox cycle performance. Li et al. [22] studied the preparation of Ce-Ti catalyst by co-precipitation method, since the presence of Ce-O-Ti active sites, the amorphous Ce-Ti oxides exhibited higher activity than their crystalline oxides at low temperature. Fei et al. [23] reported that Ce-O-Ti amorphous catalysts prepared by spontaneous deposition shown excellent catalytic activity, wide operating temperature window, and abnormal H2O/SO2 durability. Furthermore, the modification of Ce-Ti catalyst by doping other metals has also been widely studied. Zhang et al. [19] researched that Sn-doped CeTi catalyst prepared by solvothermal method possessed good catalytic activity in a wide temperature window (180–460 °C), and accompanied good SO2 resistance at 300 °C. Liu et al. [8] found that Sm doped CeO2-TiO2 mixed oxides significantly improved the NH3-SCR activity and SO2 tolerance of the catalyst. Remarkably, Zr could be used to adjust the surface acidity of the catalyst, so as to prepare the catalyst with higher activity [24]. Recently, Chen et al. [25] reported that adding a small amount of Zr enhanced the hydrothermal stability of Fe-SSZ-13 catalyst. Consequently, it is worth further delving to boost the activity and stability of the catalyst by Zr-modified CeTiOx. Additionally, research has suggested that the presence of more Ce3+ is propitious to increase defects in Ce-based catalysts [5,26]. Researchers also published that catalysts with excellent performance could be prepared by using reducing atmosphere treatment [27–30]. After reduction atmosphere treatment, the valence states of active species can be reduced, resulting in more surface defects, especially oxygen vacancies, thus enhancing the activity of metal oxide catalysts. Zheng et al. [28] reported that hydrogen pretreatment improved the NH3-SCR activity of amorphous Ce-Ti catalysts, and the treated catalyst had good sustainability. Lv et al. [29] studied that H2 pretreatment promoted the SCR performance of CeO2 catalyst, and the obtained CeO2-H catalyst owed lower crystallinity, higher reducibility and surface acidity. Previous studies were only limited to CeO2 or Ce-Ti catalysts. In this paper, the effect of Zr modification on the catalytic activity of CeTiOx was studied, and the sample with the highest activity was selected and reduced by H2, with the aim of preparing an excellent performance catalyst. The results indicated that the reduced R-Ce-Zr-Ti-Ox catalyst exhibited better activity at both low and high temperature, as well as significant H2O/SO2 tolerance than the unreduced Ce-Zr-Ti-Ox catalyst. Furthermore, various characterization techniques such as XRD, SEM, EDS, HRTEM, BET, H2-TPR, NH3-TPD, O2-TPD and XPS were performed to explore the surface composition and structure of the catalysts before and after reduction, and the reaction mechanism was researched by In situ DRIFTS. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation The catalyst was prepared by an ethylene glycol solvothermal method, in which cerium nitrate hexahydrate, zirconium nitrate pentahydrate, and tetrabutyl titanate (TBT) were used as precursors. The synthesis process was as follows: firstly, a certain proportion of Ce(NO3)3·6H2O and Zr(NO3)4·5H2O were dissolved in 15 mL ethylene glycol solution, stirring for 30 min, then a certain amount of tetrabutyl titanate (TBT) was added dropwise and continued stirring for 1 h. At the same time, 2.0 g polyether P123 template and 4.5 g urea were added into 20 mL ethylene glycol, respectively, and the template was transferred to an oil bath at 45 °C and stirred, while urea was stirred and dissolved at room temperature. After the template was completely dissolved, it was moved to room temperature to cool. Then, the template solution was added into the urea solution and stirred evenly, and then the mixture was slowly added into the precursor solution and stirred for 30 min. Subsequently, the mixed solution was transferred to the PTFE lining and reacted in an oven at 160 °C for 24 h. Ulteriorly, the products were washed with water and ethanol three times, and dried at 80 °C overnight. Finally, the obtained samples were calcined at 500 °C for 4 h (2 °C·min−1) in air. The catalysts were denoted as CZT-x/1, in which Ce: Zr: Ti = x: 1: 100 (x = 10, 15, 20, 25), the samples without Ce or Zr were marked as ZT-0/1 or CT-20/0, indicating Ce: Zr: Ti = 0: 1: 100 and Ce: Zr: Ti = 20: 0: 100, respectively. In addition, the catalysts after 20 h water and sulfur resistance test were expressed as U-S, for example, CZT-20/1 was labeled as CZT-20/1-S. 2.2 Hydrogen reduction treatment of the sample The H2-TPR of the catalyst was tested by FINESORB-3010 automatic chemical adsorption instrument of Zhejiang Pantai Instrument Co., Ltd. After the reduction curve was obtained, fresh samples were put into U-tube, and heated for a certain time at the temperature corresponding to the peak point of Ce4+→ Ce3+ reduction in the atmosphere of N2 (30 mL·min−1) and 7 vol% H2-Ar (10 mL·min−1) to obtain the reduced catalyst. 2.3 Catalyst characterization X-ray diffraction (XRD) was performed on the X'PERT PRO type diffractometer of Panalytical Company in the Netherlands. Cu/Kα with Cr monochromatization was used as the radiation source (λ = 0.15406 nm). The operating voltage and current of the X-ray tube are 40 kV and 40 mA, respectively. The step length of the X-ray tube is 0.026 and the 2θ scanning range was 5–80°. The N2 adsorption-desorption curve was tested on a Micrometric Stristari3020 analytical instrument. The samples were pretreated at 300 °C for 4 h. The pore size distribution and specific surface area of the catalyst were calculated using the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method and the Brunauer-Emmet-Teller (BET) equation. Hitachi SU8220 Scanning electron microscope (SEM) was used for testing the morphological characteristic and the element distribution of the catalyst. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and high resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) were performed on a 200 kV FEI Tecnai G2 F20 microscope. The temperature-programmed reduction of hydrogen (H2-TPR) and the temperature-programmed desorption of oxygen/ammonia ((O2/NH3-TPD)) were tested by Finesorb-3010 automatic chemisorption apparatus of Zhejiang Fantai Instrument Co., Ltd. For H2-TPR, 50 mg samples were pretreated at 110 °C in N2 atmosphere for 1 h and then cooled to room temperature. The H2-Ar mixture was used as the reducing gas, and the samples were adsorbed in H2-Ar for 30 min to reach adsorption equilibrium. Finally, the samples were raised from room temperature to 800 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C·min−1, and the data of H2-TPR was collected by TCD. For O2-TPD or NH3-TPD, 100 mg of the samples were pretreated at 200 °C for 1 h in He stream and then the sample was dropped to room temperature. The gas path was switched to 10 ml·min−1 O2 or NH3 for adsorption. After adsorption for 1 h, the He flushing pipeline was then passed through for 30 min and the temperature rose from room temperature to target temperature at a rate of 10 °C·min−1. The data of O2-TPD or NH3-TPD was collected by thermal conductivity detector (TCD). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) test was performed on Thermo Fisher Scientific ESCALAB 250XI electron spectrometer, and C1s (284.8 eV) was used for calibration. Nicolet iS50 FT-IR spectrometer was used to collect in situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectra (In situ DRIFTS). The MCT detector resolution of the spectrometer was 4 cm−1, and the scanning times were 32. A certain amount of the catalyst was filled in the reaction cell, and it was pretreated with N2 at 110 °C (NH3 adsorption-desorption tests should be pretreated at 200 °C) for 30 min to purge the water molecules and weakly adsorbed gas on the samples surface, then cooled the temperature to 30 °C to collect the background image, and then closed the N2, injecting the corresponding reaction gas for adsorption for 1 h. Finally, the temperature was raised to a certain temperature in the reaction gas atmosphere, and the infrared spectrum of the sample was collected. 2.4 Activity evaluation The activity of the catalysts was tested in a fixed-bed reactor under the following conditions: NO = NH3 = 500 ppm, O2 = 5 vol%, SO2 = 50 ppm (when used), H2O = 5 vol% (when used). 100 mg (40–60 mesh) samples were taken in a quartz tube, and pretreated at 110 °C under N2 atmosphere for 30 min. After cooling to room temperature, the reaction gas was passed into the catalyst for adsorption for 1 h, and then the temperature was raised from room temperature to a certain temperature at a step of 25 °C. The concentrations of NO, N2O and NO2 at different target temperatures were detected by FGA10 flue gas analyzer. The calculation formula of NO conversion rate and N2 selectivity was as follows: NO conversion = [ NO ] in − [ NO ] out [ NO ] in × 100 % N 2 selectivity = { 1 − 2 [ N 2 O ] out + [ N O 2 ] out [ NO ] in − [ NO ] out + [ N H 3 ] in − [ N H 3 ] out } × 100 % 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic performance test First, we studied the activity of CZT-x/1 (x = 10, 15, 20, 25) catalysts with different Ce/Zr ratios, and the results are shown in Fig. 1 (a). It is found that the activity of the catalysts becomes better at first and then becomes worse with the increase of Ce doping. When Ce doping ratio is 20%, CZT-20/1 catalyst possesses the highest NO conversion in the range of 125–250 °C. In addition, the NO conversion of CZT-20/1 decreases after 250 °C, which is caused by the excessive oxidation of NH3 to N2O and NO2 at high temperature. Therefore, the optimal Ce doping ratio in CZT-x/1 catalyst is 20. Because the redox performance of the catalyst is also an important factor for high activity, we further optimized the CZT-20/1 catalyst. In other words, the CZT-20/1 sample was reduced by H2 at 510 °C for different time z (z = 1, 2, 3, 4 h), and the activity results are displayed in Fig. S1(a). The consequence shows that R-CZT-20/1-2h exhibits the highest NO conversion at 50–400 °C. It implies that electrons on the catalyst surface are different at different reduction times. When the reduction time is 1 h, the favorable valence state is not fully excited; when the reduction time is 2 h, the valence state of each ion has reached the best ion transfer; when the reduction time is 3, 4 h, they may have been very stable and cannot reach the best electron transfer state. Moreover, too long reduction time also has a great influence on the BET of the catalyst. For comparison, the CT-20/0 sample without Zr was reduced at 510 °C for 2 h to obtain R-CT-20/0-2h in the meantime. The following R-CZT-20/1-2h and R-CT-20/0-2h are represented as R-CZT-20/1 and R-CT-20/0, respectively. As shown in Fig. 1(b), it is obviously observed that TiO2 and ZT-0/1 are inactive below 300 °C, and the maximum NO conversion was only 25% over the entire operating temperature range, indicating that neither Ti nor Zr is the active species of NH3-SCR. Typically, CT-20/0 appears great catalytic activity and reaches the highest conversion about 99% at 225 °C, but its activity is not as good as CZT-20/1. Compared with the unreduced CT-20/0 and CZT-20/1 samples, it is clear that the catalytic activity of R-CT-20/0 and R-CZT-20/1 is significantly improved at 50–200 °C. R-CT-20/0 displays better NO conversation than CT-20/0 and CZT-20/1 in low-temperature, while its activity goes down above 275 °C. As for R-CZT-20/1 catalyst, its NO conversion reaches 76% at 175 °C, which is higher than R-CT-20/0 (72%) and CZT-20/1 (66%). Moreover, it exhibits a broad temperature range (200–350 °C) with a minimum 98% conversion rate, which can be ascribed to the well-dispersed of active element Ce on the surface of R-CZT-20/1 catalyst. Beside, there is no obvious ammonia peroxidation phenomenon in the high temperature. As the selectivity of N2 is negative correlation with the concentration of 2N2O+NO2, it can be concluded from Fig. 1(b) that there are no by-products in both of CZT-20/1 and R-CZT-20/1 at low temperature, and the N2 selectivity can reach 100%. By-products are produced in CZT-20/1 at 275 °C, but less by-products are produced in R-CZT-20/1 at 375 °C, indicating that R-CZT-20/1 possesses better N2 selection at high temperature. In order to further distinguish the activities of R-CZT-20/1 and CZT-20/1 catalysts, their NO conversion under different GHSV were tested (Fig. S1(b)). It is found that the activity change of CZT-20/1 and R-CZT-20/1 shows the same trend at low and high GHSV. The stability of catalyst is also a crucial factor for NH3-SCR reaction. Therefore, the stability of R-CZT-20/1 catalyst was tested at 225 °C and 150 °C for 60 h, and the result is shown in Fig. 1(c). Obviously, the NO conversion of the R-CZT-20/1 not only remains 100% unchanged at 225 °C, but maintains approximately 33% at 150 °C, which might be related to the stable interaction between CeOx, ZrOx and TiO2. In practice, SO2 and H2O are the main components in the exhaust gas of coal-fired power plants, and the anti H2O and SO2 ability of NH3-SCR catalyst is a vital index to evaluate its performance. The H2O/SO2 endurance of CT-20/0, CZT-20/1, R-CT-20/0 and R-CZT-20/1 catalysts is carried out in Fig. 1(d). When 5 vol% H2O is injected into the feed gas, the samples change little within 3 h, indicating that water will not cause obvious deactivation of the catalyst. When water and sulfur are added simultaneously, the NO conversion of CT-20/0 gradually declines to 60%, and the activity remains unchanged after cutting off water and sulfur for 3 h, respectively. As for CZT-20/1, its catalytic activity goes down more slowly than that of CT-20/0 during the test, and the NO conversion keeps at 76% after interrupting water and sulfur. As for R-CT-20/0, its NO conversion remains at 83, 84% within 15 h of H2O and SO2, and the conversion holds about 86% after removing water and sulfur. Compared with CZT-20/1, H2 reduction plays a leading role in preventing sulfur poisoning. Noticeably, the catalytic activity of R-CZT-20/1 slowly decreases from 100% to 94% after 14 h of simultaneous H2O and SO2, and its activity tends to boost during the test. Chances are that the strong interaction among Ce-Zr-Ti can reduce the poisoning rate, and the change of valence state of the active metal ions will lead to the advance of catalytic activity after the reaction gas interacts with catalyst. Furthermore, the NO conversion restores to about 96% after breaking off water and sulfur in the 15 h tolerance test, proving that the deactivation of SO2 is reversible to some extent. In a word, both doping a small amount of Zr and reduction treatment can improve the NH3-SCR performance of the catalyst, indicating that doping a small amount of Zr is conducive to the catalytic activity, while the reduction treatment can produce more Ce3+ species and oxygen vacancies, which contributes to a more obvious synergistic effect between Ce, Zr and Ti, thus promoting the “fast SCR” reaction and H2O/SO2 tolerance. The following research will further confirm those results. 3.2 Analysis of structural characteristics (XRD, TEM, EDS and BET) Powder X-ray diffraction was used to investigate the phase structure of the catalysts, and the results are shown in Fig. 2 . It is clear that both pure TiO2 and ZT-0/1 samples exist in anatase (JCPDS #21-1272) form. The main peak intensity of TiO2 decreases obviously after doping active metal Ce. With the augment of Ce doping, the strength and number of anatase peaks gradually lessen, which is due to the amorphous form of Ce and Zr. All Ce-containing catalysts exist weak anatase diffraction peaks, implying that the samples exist in part amorphous and a small amount of anatase crystal. As for R-CZT-20/1, there is only one weak anatase peak (2θ = 25.3°), implying that there is a strong interaction among CeOx, ZrOx and TiO2, resulting in the low crystallinity form of R-CZT-20/1 catalyst, which is more avail to NH3-SCR reaction [31]. From Fig. S2, it is found that the crystallinity of TiO2 in CT-20/0-S and CZT-20/1-S lower slightly after importing H2O and SO2, while that in R-CZT-20/1-S does not change significantly. The decreased crystallinity of the unreduced samples may be due to the obvious action of the catalyst and SO2, which re-disperses the species on the surface and reduces the crystallinity. However, the unchanged after reduction indicates that SO2 has weak interaction with the surface of the catalyst and does not reduce its crystallinity, indicating that R-CZT-20/1 possesses better sulfur resistance. Ulteriorly, none of the catalysts exists sulfate peaks, which illustrates that the generated sulfate is highly dispersed and there is no crystalline sulfate species form [32]. Fig. 3 (a–f) exhibits SEM results of the samples at 10k magnification. As seen from Fig. 3(a–c), with the increase of Ce doping, the morphology of CZT-10/1, CZT-15/1 and CZT-25/1 catalysts change from large sintered blocks to mixed pieces and particles with relatively uniform dispersion. It is found that all the metal oxides with Ce/Zr = 20 exist in the form of small particles (Fig. 3(d–f)). Moreover, reduction has little effect on the particles of the sample, which are relatively uniform on the whole. The morphology of R-CZT-20/1 catalyst was further studied by TEM and EDS mappings (Figs. 3(g, h) and 3S). Fig. 3(g) displays that the morphology of R-CZT-20/1 chiefly exists as uniform particles under high power electron microscope. Fig. 3(h) presents that the lattice fringes with spacing of 0.35 nm are the (101) plane of TiO2, which matches the XRD results well. The element distribution in Fig. 3S reveals that Ce, Zr, Ti and O elements on the surface of R-CZT-20/1 are uniformly dispersed without obvious irregular accumulation. The high dispersion of the active component over the catalyst benefits the activity of the catalyst since the separated active component helps to expose more effective active sites and promotes the denitrification performance of the catalyst. Fig. 4 displays the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and the corresponding BJH desorption pore distribution curves of the catalysts, and the corresponding data are summarized in Table 1 . As shown in Fig. 4(a), the isotherms of all catalysts are typical type IV, and IUPAC judges them to be clear H2 type hysteresis loops at 0.5–1 relative pressure (p/po), which is due to the mesoporous structure between particles. The pore diameter distribution curve of these samples measured by BJH method exhibits a single peak with a center at 4.36–13.10 nm, indicating that the pore size distribution of these samples varies greatly. It can be found that the specific surface areas of the metal oxides are relatively large, among which CZT-20/1 presents the largest specific surface area and the smallest average pore diameter, which is just consistent with its activity. In addition, it has been reported that the specific surface of the catalyst is affected by calcination temperature and time [33,34], so that the reduction treatment at 510 °C for 2 h might be the reason why the specific surface area of R-CZT-20/1 is not the largest. It is well known that the specific surface area is not the exclusive factor to determine the activity of the catalyst [35], and the samples will be further characterized and analyzed. 3.3 Redox and surface acidity of catalysts It is well known that the redox performance of SCR catalyst is closely related to its activity. Fig. 5 (a) displays the H2-TPR profiles of TiO2, CT-20/0 and CZT-x/1 catalysts from 150 °C to 800 °C, and the reduction peaks are fitted with Gaussian-Lorentz function. The reduction area of H2 consumption are presented in Table S1. It can be seen that pure TiO2 exhibits a very weak reduction peak at 613 °C (ε), and CT-20/0 and CZT-x/1 also exist such a peak, which is the reduction peak of Ti4+→ Ti3+ on the surface of catalyst since Zr has no reduction peak below 800 °C [36]. As for CT-20/0 and CZT-x/1 catalysts, they exhibit four broad reduction peaks centered at 344 °C (α), 450 °C (β), 512 °C (γ) and 613 °C (ε), among which the former three are attributed to the reduction of surface active oxygen, surface lattice oxygen (Ce4+→ Ce3+) and bulk lattice oxygen (Ce4+→ Ce3+), respectively [8,35,37,38]. Compared with CT-20/0 and CZT-x/1 (x = 10, 15) catalysts (354 °C), the position of the α peak shifts to lower temperature (332 °C) over CZT-20/1 catalyst, while that move to higher temperature (366 °C) over CZT-25/1, suggesting the CZT-20/1 catalyst shows the best reducibility among the samples. Furthermore, the β peak of CZT-25/1 also shows higher temperature (461 °C) than that of other catalysts (450 °C) together with the γ peak (528 °C). According to Table S1, it is found that the low-temperature activity of the catalysts is positively correlated with the amounts of H2 consumption. CZT-20/1 possesses the most H2 consumption in all samples, signifying that the addition of Zr species promotes the reducibility of CZT-20/1, and only a certain proportion of Ce is propitious to reinforce the synergistic effect of Ce-Zr-Ti. It has been reported that the synergistic effect can produce a large number of oxygen vacancies, and the oxygen vacancies promote the diffusion of oxygen to the catalyst surface and further penetrate into the bulk, which all stimulate the NH3-SCR reaction [32]. The O2-TPD curves of the catalysts are shown in Fig. 5(b), and the curve fitting results are shown in Table S2. The catalysts are deconvolved into three desorption peaks at 100–500 °C, which are donated as α, β and γ, respectively. The α peak (∼170 °C) corresponds to the surface physical adsorption of oxygen. The β peak (∼240 °C) is attributed to the adsorbed O2− or O−, which is related to surface oxygen defects. Beside, the γ peak (∼345 °C) is attributed to the surface lattice oxygen [8,39]. From Table S2, it is found that CZT-20/1 emerges the largest O2 adsorption content instead of R-CZT-20/1. However, R-CZT-20/1 exhibits the supreme β/(α+β+γ) ratio (55.59%). It is well known that containing more surface oxygen defects is more beneficial to NH3-SCR reaction. As for the Zr-modified CZT-20/1 catalyst, its ability to store oxygen is the strongest, which makes it most active among the unreduced catalysts. As a key step of NH3-SCR reaction, the adsorption of NH3 on the catalysts largely hangs on their surface acidity. Hence, the distribution of acid sites and the change of surface acidity are determined by NH3-TPD analysis. NH3-TPD curves of different samples are shown in Fig. 5(c). All catalysts are fitted into three peaks, and the fitting results are shown in Table S3. The first desorption peak is approximately at 150 °C, which belongs to physical adsorbed NH3, the second peak locating roughly at 235 °C is attributed to the weak acid desorption of NH3, and the third peak is at about 360 °C, which is assigned to a strong acid desorption of NH3 [24,40]. By comparing the desorption peak areas reflected by TPD curves (Table S3), it is found that the acid sites of R-CZT-20/1 catalyst is most, which could be significantly increased after H2 reduction. At the same time, we can find that Zr-doped CZT-20/1 carries the most acid sites among the unreduced samples, which make it reveal the best low-temperature activity. Abundant active components on the surface brings about maximum acid sites on R-CZT-20/1, and there is strong interaction among these active species, implying that enriching Ce3+ and oxygen vacancy are conducive to adsorb more NH3. Combining the results of O2-TPD, we draw a conclusion that the R-CZT-20/1 catalyst probably adsorbs more NH3 which interacts with surface oxygen vacancies, accelerating the process of the catalytic reaction, resulting in the best NH3-SCR performance. According to the literature, the coordination unsaturated cation center can generate L acid, and the number of L acid will increase with the augment of oxygen vacancy defects [41], it is also the possible reason for the largest amount of acid sites in R-CZT-20/1. As shown in Fig. 7, the acid sites mainly belong to L acids, this is due to the desorption of B acids at medium temperature and high temperature mainly leaves L acids. 3.4 Surface composition and chemical state of catalysts Fig. 6 displays the XPS spectra of Ti 2p, Ce 3d, and O 1s for different samples. Using the Gauss-Lorentz function to fit the XPS curves, and the results are summarized in Table 2 . As shown in Fig. 6(a), the Ti 2p binding energies of all samples are located at ∼464.2 eV and ∼458.4 eV, corresponding to Ti 2p1/2 and Ti 2P3/2, respectively, implying that the Ti species exhibit +4 valence state [31,32,41]. Compared with CT-20/0 and CZT-20/1, the binding energy of Ti over R-CZT-20/1 shifts to higher binding energy by 0.2 eV, manifesting that electron transfer among Ce, Zr and Ti in the reduction process, which leads to the decrease of electrons cloud density around Ti, that is to say, there is a synergistic effect among Ce-Zr-Ti. The spectral results of Ce 3d are presented in Fig. 6(b). The v and u series peaks of Ce 3d come from 3d5/2 and 3d3/2 states respectively, and the XPS spectra of Ce 3d can be divided into eight characteristic peaks. One group marked as v (881.3 eV), v″ (886.6 eV), v‴ (897.5 eV) is contributed by 3d3/2 of Ce4+, and another group denoted as u (900.4 eV), u″ (906.6 eV) and u‴ (915.9 eV) is contributed by d5/3 of Ce4+. In addition, peaks labeled as u' (902.9 eV) and v' (883.9 eV) correspond to the 3d3/2 state of Ce3+ [14,42,43]. The atomic concentration and Ce3+/(Ce3++ Ce4+) ratio of the samples are summarized in Table 2. As for the fresh samples, the relative content of Ce3+ on the surface ranges from 25.42% to 30.46%, and the highest content of Ce3+ is found in CZT-20/1 (30.46%). Associated with Fig. S4 (a) and Table S4, it proves that H2 reduction treatment promotes the production of active substance Ce3+. More Ce3+ means the more frequent conversion between Ce3+and Ce4+, which is conducive to the migration of active oxygen species, as well as the electron transfer between Ce3++ Ti4+→ Ce4++ Ti3+. Moreover, the transformation from Ce4+ to Ce3+ during the H2 reduction process produces charge imbalance and surface oxygen vacancies, which will accelerate the adsorption of oxygen or the activation of reactants in NH3-SCR reactions [44]. According to Fig. S4 (c) and Table S4, the increase of Ce3+ species in CZT-20/1-S and CT-20/0-S catalysts is due to the fact that SO2 can react with CeO2 species to generate Ce2(SO4)3 in the presence of O2. Notably, there are fewer Ce3+ species in R-CZT-20/1-S (30.87%) than that in the fresh sample, since the main responsibility of Ce is Ce3+ interacting with the reaction gas rather than CeO2 reacting with SO2 during the NH3-SCR reaction, which will produce less sulfate. Fig. 6(c) shows the O 1s spectra of the catalysts. The peaks of O 1s can be divided into three peaks at 529.4 - 529.6 eV, 530.2 - 530.8 eV and 531.5 - 532.3 eV, corresponding to lattice oxygen (Oγ), surface chemisorbed oxygen (Oβ); and the hydroxyl group including adsorbed water (Oα) [32,45], respectively. It is known that surface adsorbed oxygen is generally considered as the main active species due to its better fluidity compared with the lattice oxygen and plays a significant role in the redox reaction [24,39]. It can be seen from Table 2 that the relative content of Oβ in CZT-x/1 catalysts increase from 32.98% (CZT-10/1) to 36.62% (CZT-20/1), and the most Oβ exists in CZT-20/1, which makes it perform the best activity in CZT-x/1 catalysts. Crucially, R-CZT-20/1 contains the largest Oβ/(Oα+Oβ+Oγ) ratio, which contributes greatly to its low-temperature NH3-SCR performance. From Fig. S4 (b) and Table S4, it can be concluded that the increase of Oβ/(Oα+Oβ+Oγ) ratio is attributed to more oxygen vacancies generated after the catalysts are reduced, which leads to the increase of chemisorbed oxygen species. More Oβ species are found in R-CZT-20/1 rather than R-CT-20/0 which is the same as CZT-20/1 and CT-20/0, suggesting that a bit of Zr doping augments the surface adsorbed oxygen species. As shown in Fig. S4(d), more Oβ can be detected in CT-20/0-S and CZT-20/1-S than that in the fresh samples, which is due to the formation of sulfate on the surface. Moreover, there are more Oβ species in CT-20/0-S comparing with CZT-20/1-S, indicating that the amount of sulfate on CT-20/0-S is further than that on CZT-20/1-S combined with the atomic concentration of S (Table S4). Therefore, the vulcanized R-CZT-20/1-S produces little sulfate, resulting in the least Oβ content of it. The S 2p spectra of the catalysts after the water and sulfur resistance test are shown in Fig. 6(d), and the spectra is divided into four peaks. The binding energy at 167.8 eV and 169.6 eV belongs to S4+, while at 167.0 eV and 168.7 eV belongs to S6+ [46], and the corresponding sulfates are SO3 2− and SO4 2−, respectively, which can be observed from the FT-IR spectrum (Fig. S5). Comparing the ratio of S6+ (Table S4), it is found that the sulfur resistance of the catalyst is inversely proportional to the content of S6+, which agrees that R-CZT-20/1 possesses the best sulfur tolerance, followed by CZT-20/1, illustrating that the less SO4 2− accumulated on the catalyst surface, the better the sulfur resistance. 3.5 In situ drifts analysis The R-CZT-20/1 with the best performance, the unreduced CZT-20/1 and the Zr-free CT-20/0 catalysts were selected for In situ DRIFTS characterization (including NH3 adsorption, NO + O2 and NH3 + NO + O2 co-adsorption), and then the formation and transformation of the surface species and intermediates of the catalysts were explored to understand the reaction mechanism. 3.5.1 NH3 adsorption In order to better understand the behavior of NH3 and obtain the surface species information of NH3-SCR catalysts at 50–300 °C, the NH3 adsorption test was carried out on the samples. The reactant gas is 500 ppm NH3 and the corresponding results are shown in Fig. 7 (a–c). When the catalysts are exposed to NH3, the absorption peaks at 1129–1200 cm−1,1358 cm−1,1438–1465 cm−1,1508–1512 cm−1,1546–1562 cm−1,1595 cm−1,1671 cm−1 and 3154–3360 cm−1 are observed. The bands at 1129–1200 cm−1 and 1595 cm−1 are attributed to the symmetric and asymmetric bending vibration of the N-H bond in coordinated NH3 at L acid sites [32,43], respectively. The absorption peaks of R-CZT-20/1 and CZT-20/1 catalysts at 1160 cm−1 and 1174 cm−1 blue shift, respectively, which is due to the hydrogen bond fracture between chemically adsorbed NH3 groups [24]. The bands at 1438–1465 cm−1 and 1671 cm−1 are assigned to the asymmetric and symmetric bending vibration of NH4 + species at B acid sites [5,12,35], respectively. The peak located at 1358 cm−1 is related to the oxidation of adsorbed ammonia species [47]. The absorption peaks at 1508–1512 cm−1 and 1540–1562 cm−1 are amide compounds (-NH2) produced by dehydrogenation of NH3 coordinated with L acid sites [48–50]; The N-H stretching vibration mode of coordinated NH3 is also observed at the high wave number of 3154–3360 cm−1 [44]. It can be observed that the NH3 adsorption curves of CT-20/0, CZT-20/1 and R-CZT-20/1 catalysts are similar, and the results can be obtained at following: (1) all catalysts contain L and B acid sites, and the amount of L acid sites are more than that of B acid sites in general; (2) L acid exists at both high and low temperatures, while B acid gradually decreases with the increase of temperature, revealing that L acid exhibits better thermal stability, while B acid mainly works at low temperature, this can be analyzed combining with NH3-TPD results; (3) CZT-20/1 catalyst possesses more L and B acids sites during the test, so that the property of CZT-20/1 is better than CT-20/0; (4) As for CZT-20/1 and R-CZT-20/1, it is found that R-CZT-20/1 owns an extra L acid peak (1129 cm−1), combining with peak intensity shows that R-CZT-20/1 contains more L acid. Noticeably, it finds that R-CZT-20/1 presents -NH2 peak at low temperature, in combination with the XPS results, it can be concluded that the existence of frequent conversion between Ce4+ and Ce3+ is conducive to the adsorption and activation of the NH3 component to produce -NH2 [8], and the -NH2 group can react with NO to promote the reaction as Eq. (1). (1) NH2 + NO → NH2NO → N2 + H2O 3.5.2 NO + O2 co-adsorption The NO + O2 co-adsorption results of CT-20/0, CZT-20/1 and R-CZT-20/1 catalysts are shown in Fig. 8 . When the catalysts were exposed to NO + O2, the peaks of monodentate nitrite (∼1086, ∼1092, 1121 cm−1), chelated nitrite (1200 cm−1), bridging nitrate (1243 cm−1), monodentate nitrate (1292 cm−1), linear nitrite (1483–1493 cm−1), bidentate nitrate (∼1560, 1565 cm−1), free nitrate ion (1368 cm−1) and gaseous NO2 adsorption (1612 cm−1) are detected [5,33,43,45,51]. It can be found that the adsorption conditions of CZT-20/1 and CT-20/0 catalysts are the same. With the increase of temperature, the peak of monodentate nitrate (1292 cm−1) gradually decreases, accompanied by the appearance of bridged nitrate (1243 cm−1) and the generation of more bidentate nitrate, indicating that unstable monodentate nitrate is converted into bridging and bidentate nitrate. As we can see, more and more bidentate nitrate appears, as well as new species such as free nitrate, monodentate and linear nitrite, implying that more nitrates species adsorb on the surface of catalysts with temperature risen, which are relatively stable and difficult to be decomposed. However, the R-CZT-20/1 is slightly different from CZT-20/1 and CT-20/0, and only chelated nitrite (1200 cm−1) exists at low temperature on it. With the increase of temperature, chelated nitrite gradually disappears and the peak intensity of bidentate nitrate increases continuously (1565 cm−1), proving that chelated nitrite is oxidized to bidentate nitrate and releases active sites. There is an extra monodentate nitrite peak (1121 cm−1) over R-CZT-20/1, which may benefit its catalytic activity. Furthermore, linear nitrite is proved to be inactive species in transient reaction experiments [45], so they are stable in steady-state SCR reaction. 3.5.3 NH3 + NO + O2 co-adsorption The results of NH3 + NO + O2 co-adsorption of the catalysts are shown in Fig. 9 . When the catalysts were exposed to NH3 + NO + O2, the following peaks appeared: monodentate nitrite (∼1086, 1121 cm−1), NH3 coordinated with L acid sites (∼1174, 1200 cm−1), chelated nitrite (1200 cm−1), NH4NO3 (∼1348, 1350 cm−1) [41,42], free NO3 − (1368 cm−1), NH4 + species attached to B acid sites (1435–1465 cm−1, 1671 cm−1), linear nitrite (∼1490, 1493 cm−1), the coincident peaks of bidentate nitrate and amide species -NH2 (∼1560, 1565 cm−1), adsorbed NO2 molecules (1612 cm−1), and N-H stretching vibrations related to coordinated NH3 (3148–3383 cm−1). As for CT-20/0 and CZT-20/1 catalysts, L and B acids are present throughout the temperature range, and the increasing of the peak of NH4 +at 1671 cm−1 suggests that the amount of B acid grows on the catalyst surface, which may be caused by the formation of water during the adsorption [8]. At the same time, we found that the peak intensity of NO2 is much weaker than that of O2 + NO adsorption alone, indicating that NO2 is easy to combine with NH4 + to obtain NH4NO2, which is quickly decomposed into N2 and H2O in NH3-SCR reaction. On the contrary, the adsorption of bidentate nitrate on the catalyst surface increases with the rising of temperature, which means that bidentate nitrate is inactive and aggregates on the surface of the catalyst. Different from CT-20/0, Zr-doped CZT-20/1 appears a new band assigned to NH4NO3 (1348 cm−1) at 175 °C, result in better catalytic performance of CZT-20/1 than CT-20/0 catalyst. Notably, only NH3 absorption peaks exist in CT-20/0 and CZT-20/1 catalysts before 175 °C, while they both present the adsorption peaks of NH3 and NO + O2 after 175 °C, proving that they follow the E-R mechanism before 175 °C and L-H reaction mechanism after 175 °C. The adsorption of R-CZT-20/1 catalyst is the same as that of CZT-20/1. Interestingly, with the increase of temperature, the intensity of NH4NO3 peak at 1350 cm−1 is even stronger, indicating that the presence of abundant NH4NO3 is more conducive to the NH3-SCR reaction, which makes the activity of R-CZT-20/1 catalyst significantly higher than that of CZT-20/1 catalyst. In addition, the NH3 adsorption peak at 1174 cm−1 of R-CZT-20/1 catalyst is gradually consumed with the increase of temperature, which may be caused by NH3 capturing hydrogen protons and converting them to NH4 +. Therefore, the generation of NH4 + and NH4NO3 is conducive to enhance catalytic activity. Meanwhile, we found that the chelated nitrite (1200 cm−1) in R-CZT-20/1 catalyst is rapidly consumed at low temperature, and the adsorbed NO2 (1612 cm−1) is also consumed at high temperature, which confirms that the chelated nitrite and NO2 are the active species. At the same time, there may be a rapid transformation process of NH4 ++ NO2 → NH4NO2 → H2O + N2. As a result, R-CZT-20/1 catalyst mainly follows L-H reaction mechanism. 3.6 Possible reaction mechanism Based on the above results, the possible mechanism of NH3-SCR reaction over CT-20/0, CZT-20/1, R-CZT-20/1 is proposed. NH4 + is considered to be an important active species, which is obtained by NH3 acquiring hydrogen protons as Eq. (2). During the reaction, the presence of NO2 in the catalysts is mainly caused by lattice distortion of Ce-O-Ti bond under strong interaction which induced by masses of surface chemisorption oxygen as shown in Eq. (3) [45,46], as well as it can be obtained by the reaction of gaseous NO and O2 as Eq. (4). Generally, NO2 is considered to be the key intermediate species to trigger the “fast SCR” reaction Eq. (5)). Conspicuously, NO + O2 + NH3 co-adsorption certificates that doping Zr into CT-20/0 or reduction treatment to CZT-20/1 are conducive to the formation of NH4NO3 species on the surface of CZT-20/1 and R-CZT-20/1 catalysts after 175 °C. NH4NO3 is widely reported as the intermediate product and it can react with NO or NO and NH3 to generate N2 and H2O [52] (Eqs. (6), ((7)). Different from CT-20/0 and CZT-20/1, In situ DRIFTS spectra of NO + O2 adsorption experiment finds that there is chelated nitrite over R-CZT-20/1 at low temperature. Chelated nitrite can undergo SCR reaction with NH4 + provided by B acid site, and it is considered as an active intermediate substance Eq. (8)), which significantly enhanced the low-temperature activity of R-CZT-20/1 catalyst. The above analysis shows that NH4 + and NO2 are the active species on the catalyst surface during the reaction process; NH4NO3 is an important intermediate product over CZT-20/1 and R-CZT-20/1 catalysts, and chelated nitrite is an important active intermediate species of R-CZT-20/1 catalyst at low temperature. In conclusion, the NH3-SCR reaction on CT-20/0 surface (E-R) is suggested mainly following Eqs. (2)–((5), and that on CZT-20/1 surface (E-R) following Eqs. (2)–(7), while that on R-CZT-20/1 surface (L-H) following Eqs. (2)–(8) (see Fig. 10 ). (2) NH3 (ad) + H+ → NH4 + (ad) (3) NO (g) + O* (ad) → NO2 (ad) (4) NO (g) + 1/2O2 (g) → NO2 (ad) (5) NH4 + (ad) + NO2 (ad) → NH4NO2 → N2 (g) + H2O (6) NH4NO3 + NO → NO2 + N2 (g)+ 2H2O (7) 1/2NH4NO3 + NO + NH3 → 3/2N2 (g) + 5/2H2O (8) NO2 − (ad) + NH4 +/(NH3) (ad) + (H+) → NH4NO2 (ad) → N2 + 2H2O ad: adsorption; O*(ad): chemisorbed oxygen. 4 Conclusion A series of Zr-modified CZT-x/1 catalysts were synthesized by solvothermal method, and the catalyst with better performance was obtained by H2 reduction treatment. The performance test revealed that Zr doping could improve the activity and H2O/SO2 tolerance of CZT-20/1. After H2 reduction treatment, R-CZT-20/1 exhibited better catalytic activity than CZT-20/1 and possessed excellent H2O/SO2 resistance as well as good reversibility. The characterization results showed that there was strong synergistic effect among Ce-Zr-Ti component after reduction treatment, which promoted the existence of the catalyst with low crystallinity, and inhibited the rapid sulfurization of the catalyst. At the same time, XPS analysis showed that there were more active substance Ce3+ and chemisorbed oxygen on the catalyst surface after reduction, which accelerated the redox cycle of Ce3+/Ce4+ and produced more oxygen vacancies. Among them, the presence of Zr promoted the favorable process. In situ DRIFTs analysis revealed that the surface of R-CZT-20/1 catalyst could adsorb more NH3 and NOx species and provided more active sites. The chelated nitrite and NO2 adsorbed on the surface of R-CZT-20/1 were active species, and NH4NO3 was an important reaction intermediate. Finally, the results indicated that the unreduced CT-20/0 and CZT-20/1 catalysts followed the E-R mechanism before 175 °C and L-H reaction mechanism after 175 °C, while R-CZT-20/1 followed L-H mechanism in NH3-SCR reaction. coredata.dc:description: The Zr-modified CeTiOx mixed oxide catalyst with good NH3-SCR activity and SO2 resistance was synthesized and reduced by H2. Performance test revealed that the obtained R-CZT-20/1 (Ce: Zr: Ti = 20: 1: 100) catalyst exhibited outstanding low-temperature activity after H2 reduction treatment, which achieved upon 98% NO conversion at 200–350 °C. Remarkably, it possessed excellent SO2 resistance as well as good reversibility, with the activity decreased from 100% to 96%. Meanwhile, R-CZT-20/1 possessed more surface acid sites and oxygen defects, which promoted the chemical adsorption and activation of NO and NH3 on the catalyst surface. XPS results confirmed that R-CZT-20/1 enriched Ce3+, accelerated the electron transfer between Ce3++ Ti4+ → Ce4++ Ti3+, and generated a large number of oxygen vacancies. Moreover, there is strong synergistic effect between Ce-Zr-Ti, which might be the reason for the excellent SO2 resistance. Among them, the presence of Zr facilitated the favorable process. In situ DRIFTS experiments indicated that the unreduced catalysts followed E-R and L-H mechanism at low and high temperatures, respectively, while R-CZT-20/1 obeyed only the L-H mechanism.
coredata.dc:title: Significantly enhanced activity and SO2 resistance of Zr-modified CeTiOx catalyst for low-temperature NH3-SCR by H2 reduction treatment
